awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms and evolution of thermogenic capacity in high-altitude deer mice
awd_abstract_narration:
Adaptation to high altitude environments poses some of the most extreme challenges for endothermic ("warm-blooded") animals such as mammals that strongly depend on metabolically generated heat for maintaining the body temperature. Metabolic heat generation occurs predominantly through oxygen-dependent (aerobic) metabolism, and reduced oxygen availability (hypoxia) at high altitude may limit the capacity for maintaining of the optimal body temperature. This study will use populations of deer mice (Peromyscus maniculatus) adapted to different altitudes as a model to determine which physiological mechanisms permit them to survive under hypoxic and cold conditions of high altitudes. The PIs will use a combination of physiological, genetic and metabolic studies to identify the potentially adaptive traits in mice at different altitudes and use modeling approach to integrate these traits and link them to the organism?s fitness in different environments. Although this study focuses on the populations of deer mice, many molecular and physiological mechanisms of metabolic regulation and thermoregulation are highly conserved among the mammals; therefore, the findings of this study will have implications for understanding physiological adaptations to cold and hypoxia in high-altitude populations of other mammals including humans.  This project integrates research with diverse and extensive educational and public outreach activities including training of graduate and undergraduate students, fostering international collaborations, workshops for high school teachers and public displays at a local museum. 

The goal of this research project is to identify the mechanistic basis of adaptive population differences in thermogenic capacity between deer mice that are native to different elevations. The investigators will conduct common-garden acclimation experiments in captive-bred, pedigreed mice to assess the roles of phenotypic plasticity and genotypic specialization in adaptation to different altitudes. Measures of whole-animal thermogenic capacity will be integrated with measures of various subordinate traits and a functional genomic analysis of the underlying regulatory networks. The scale of this systems-level analysis, which involves a sophisticated modeling effort to integrate a comprehensive set of physiological, genetic and metabolic variables, has never before been attempted. This research will yield important insights into the mechanistic basis of physiological adaptation to the combined challenges of hypoxia and cold exposure. This research involves an important collaboration with investigators at McMaster University in Canada, who have specialized expertise and access to facilities required for conduct of some experiments. A component of the foreign collaboration will be research experiences at McMaster University for undergraduate students from the University of Nebraska - Lincoln, and the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign. The undergraduate research experiences are being supported by co-funding from the International Science and Engineering section of the Office of International and Integrative Activities. Stories about life in extreme environments exert a powerful hold on the public imagination, and the investigators will capitalize on this fascination to develop a public outreach program that is centered on the "Sunday with a Scientist" program at the University of Nebraska State Museum. Programs will be developed for the general public that will focus on 'adaptation to extreme environments'. At the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, researchers will be involved in a series of workshops in evolutionary biology aimed at assisting high school teachers to develop tools and effective approaches to teach evolutionary biology using examples from this research.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this research was to identify the mechanistic basis of adaptive differences in aerobic performance under hypoxia between populations of deer mice (Peromyscus maniculatus). Because they have the broadest elevational distribution of any North American mammal, occurring below sea-level on the floor of Death Valley to summits of the highest mountains in the western US, deer mice are a promising model system to understand genetic and physiological mechanisms that set performance limits at high elevation. In short, this research was aimed at understanding what limits aerobic performance under hypoxia in lowlanders, and how evolutionary adaptation has equipped highlanders to surmount these limits. To do this, we conducted common-garden acclimation experiments on captive-bred mice derived from high- and low-altitude populations in the western US. These mice were born and reared at low elevation, and then acclimated to simulated high-altitude conditions in the lab. These experiments allowed us to assess the relative roles of acclimation and evolutionary adaptation in improving aerobic performance. More specifically, they allowed us to ask whether acclimation responses in lowlanders would be sufficient to achieve the level performance exhibited by native highlanders, or whether evolution had equipped highlanders with unique adaptations that allowed them achieve a higher level of performance.

Following our acclimation experiments, we integrated measures of whole-animal aerobic performance with measures of various lower-level physiological traits that influence oxygen transport and consumption (e.g. breath rate, blood oxygen saturation, density and number of capillaries in muscle). These physiological analyses were used to construct computer models that can predict which physiological traits exert the greatest influence over increases in aerobic performance. We then integrated these physiological analyses with genome-wide surveys of gene expression to understand how changes in the expression of genes relates to hypoxia acclimation, and how these gene expression responses differ between highlanders and lowlanders. This systems-level analysis is among the most detailed studies of the mechanistic basis of physiological acclimation and evolutionary adaptation to high-altitude environments that has been performed to date. As such, it resulted a number of fundamental discoveries that have broad implications for fields from evolutionary biology and ecological physiology to human exercise performance and biomedicine.  

Major results stemming from this award include the identification of key physiological traits that improve aerobic performance under hypoxia and a number of new candidate genes that underlie variation in these traits. We also gained new mechanistic insights into why acclimation responses in lowlanders are not sufficient for them to achieve the level of performance that native highlanders can achieve. In addition, this work resulted in the development of new analytical tools that will be of use to the broader comparative physiology and evolutionary genomics communities. 

In addition to these scientific advances, this project involved three postdoctoral researchers, four graduate students, and several undergraduates who all worked within a international collaborative network. Given its multidisciplinary nature, this project is well-suited for integrative training of junior scientists. In the coming years, the major advances in most biological fields will likely come through cross-disciplinary studies that integrate across multiple levels of biological organization. This project is ideally suited for scientific training in this type of integrative biology. It also provides a compelling illustration of how comparative and evolutionary physiology can provide novel insights that may have unexpected implications for improving human health and performance. Thus, trainees on this project were provided broad training experiences that will leave them well-positioned to pursue varied careers in STEM fields. Toward this end, project trainees benefited from individualized mentoring plans that were tailored to their individual career goals and career stages, in addition to the specialized training and research skills they gained through their participation in the project.
